author: Tom Morgan
title: Foreign Office faces living wage row after cleaners claim they are dismissed over pay complaint
text:
Politics Foreign Office faces living wage row after cleaners claim they are dismissed over pay complaint Fourteen workers claim they have been hit with disciplinary action after pointing out they earn a fifth less than salary levels calculated by experts Katy Rojas, 44, who said she was laid off "completely out of the blue" Photo: Eddie Mulholland/The Telegraph By Tom Morgan , Special Correspondent 12:01AM BST 19 Oct 2015 Follow 
The Government is facing a hypocrisy row over living wage targets after a group of Foreign Office cleaners claimed they were laid off for complaining about their pay packets. "I am completely sure it is only because I spoke up for my co-workers about the living wage" Katy Rojas, cleaner 
Three workers have been made redundant and another 11 say they have been hit with disciplinary action since writing to the Foreign Secretary to point out they were earning 22 per cent less than levels calculated by experts to be enough to live on. 
A campaign to boost London wages to £9.15-an-hour was previously backed by Boris Johnson while George Osborne has recently announced legislation to boost the pay packets of over 25s . 
Among those made redudant is Katy Rojas, 44, who said she was laid off "completely out of the blue". 
Photo: Alamy 
Ms Rojas started working for the FCO in 2010 on a wage of £6-an-hour, which only increased this year to £7.05. 
Interserve, which is contracted by the Government, told Ms Rojas she had failed a redundancy matrix. 
"I am completely sure it is only because I spoke up for my co-workers about the living wage," she told The Telegraph. 
Interserve deny redundancies were connected with the letter but Ms Rojas added: "I have always done my job, I have been praised for the quality of my work - it's devastating. They even sent me to Lancaster House to clean as I was the best cleaner." "This is a gross injustice" Citizens UK 
The 14 cleaners embroiled in the row signed a letter on July 21 congratulating Philip Hammond on his new role and seeking a meeting to discuss the Living Wage. 
Six weeks later, they received a letter from Interserve initiating a disciplinary process, accusing them of “bringing the contract into disrepute” for writing to the Minister. 
Ms Rojas said she was made redundant because the company claimed she was unable to use cleaning machines - even though she had never been asked to do so. 
"I did nothing wrong," she said. "I had no understanding of what happened. I'm from Ecuador and I feel so sad because I didn't think we would be treated like this. I feel like we had more workers rights at home." 
Katy Rojas Photo: Eddie Mulholland/The Telegraph 
It is understood the redundancies were initially launched as the Foreign Office is moving from Old Admiralty Building to smaller premises at King Charles Street. 
Citizens UK, which has led the campaign for the higher voluntary living wage, will deliver a letter to Mr Hammond demanding that the disciplinary action is dropped. 
The letter says: "This is a gross injustice, especially in the context of the Government’s summer budget and professed support for those on the lowest rates of pay. 
"In writing to you as the Minister, the cleaners were simply exercising their democratic right. We hope you are as shocked as we are at the action taken by your contractor, Interserve, and that you share our view that this needs to be rectified as soon as possible." 
Reverend Rosemia Brown, of Citizens UK and St James Church, Hackney, said: “Time and again we are told to take up the issue of low pay with the cleaning contractor, but we know that they work to the requirements set by the FCO. That’s why we are appealing directly to the Foreign Secretary, Philip Hammond and asking him to review his department’s contract and help the cleaners who have been disciplined simply for writing a polite letter. "Surely he can’t agree that writing a letter is cause for disciplinary action? That’s simply not right.” 
Paul Jennings, partner at law firm Bates Wells and Braithwaite, who represents a group of the employees, said: “This is a genuinely troubling case. A number of employees raised legitimate concerns with the Secretary of State about levels of pay and the difficulties they face meeting the cost of living. 
"The letter to the minister was professional and courteous. It conveyed a very compelling and personal account of the pressures faced by people working as cleaners within the Foreign and Commonwealth Office." 
​Interserve said in a statement: “Interserve is committed to paying its employees a fair wage and our personnel will benefit from the new National Living Wage when it comes in effect next year. 
“Following the FCO’s decision to close Old Admiralty Building we are reducing the number of cleaning staff on the account and have been in a process of consultation with employees and unions over the proposed changes. This is now drawing to a close and a number of people will be affected by redundancy. 
“This process has been undertaken in full cooperation with unions and employee representatives and has no bearing on any other employee issues.”​
